w:r.w:t: Coca-Cola is a carbonated soft drink that is produced by The Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta, Georgia. In 1886 the drink was founded by John Pemberton

a pharmacist trying to create an elixir for medicinal purposes. The syrup was to be mixed with seltzer water from soda fountains, which were very popular back in the late 1900's. "The first servings of Coca
Cola were sold for 5 cents per glass. During the first year, sales averaged a modest nine servings per day in Atlanta. Today, daily servings of Coca
Cola beverages are estimated at 1.9 billion globally
logo was designed and penned by Pemberton's bookkeeper Frank Mason Robinson in 1885. Robinson suggested the name "Coca-Cola"
after the two main ingredients, c
ocaine which was taken from the coca leaves
and caffeine taken from kola nuts. He suggested to Pemberton that instead of a "K" that they use a "C" because the two "C"s would appear
started marketing the drink using a serif font. The next year
logo. Robinson penned the script himself using Spencerian Style script which was very popular at the
was even used in schools when teaching children how to write.
In 1892, the Coca-Cola formula and brand were acquired by a business man named Asa Griggs Candler. His marketing tactics led the distribution of Coca
Cola to expand to soda fountains beyond Atlanta, then to its dominance of the world soft-drink market throughout the 20th century
In 1894 Mississippi a shop owner named Joseph A. Biedenharn was impressed by Coca
Cola that he bottled it in what was a common glass bottle at the time
called a "Hutchinson" and sent a case
to Asa Griggs Candler. At first Candler was polite and thanked him, but never accepted Biedenham's initial offer to bottle the drink because he thought bottling would not take off
in the first decade of the twentieth century. B
ecause of the success of Coca-Cola, there were
imitators; basically other bottling companies were trying to copy-cat Coke
by imitating the look of the bottle, or by playing off the name. Also there was the issue that the
among the 1,000 bottling plants at the time
the bottlers agreed that a distinctive beverage needed a standard disti
Benjamin Thomas, co-founder of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company, came up with a solution to the problem Coca-Cola was facing

he stated, ‚ÄúWe need a bottle which a person can recognize as a Coca-Cola bottle when he feels it in the dark.‚Äù The Coca-Cola Company decided to launch a competition among bottle suppliers. The objective was to come up with a distinctive design
. Earl R. Dean who worked for the Root Glass Bottling company came up with the
it on the same two ingredients that inspired Robinson for the name
the shapes of the kola nut and the coca leaf
The Coca-Cola Company started with one drink, Coca-Cola
n 1886 and over the years the
into a corporation that owns thousands of drinks and branding
is what is documented more than anything else
a great example of how recognizable and unique the branding of
they simply insert the words "The" before the Coca-Cola
logo and "Company" after it. There are various
that are currently being used that make up Coca-Cola's corporate identity system.
written in Spencerian script which is now a modernized version of the original script logo scripted by Robinson. Over the course of its history
, both interchangeably and separately. The main components of the
he lettering, the colors, the "dynamic wave", the bottle shape, and of course the "Coke" nickname.
uses a script type font called
Spencerian script which was a popular style in the late 1900's. This was the original logo except it is
more refined whereas originally it was handwritten.

The script spells out the words "Coca" and "Cola" with a hyphen in the middle. The first "C" has a tail on the bottom that underlines the "oca". The second "C"¬†has a tail on top that swoops over the top of "ola" and it threads through the "l".
and is at the forefront of their corporate website. The
a transparent or white background. But it is more commonly used on packaging and advertising as
, with the red for the background and white is used for the lettering.
In addition to the main logo, Coca-Cola uses a few more designs to represent the brand and they are very important to the corporate identity.

The "dynamic ribbon" or "dynamic wave" is another element that usually is placed below the lettering. It is called many things such as the swirl, the spiral, the wave, and the ribbon. The color of the wave matches the color of the lettering. It basically starts to the left of the lettering and curves downward below the word "Cola" where it becomes much thinner,

it curves upward and thickens as it goes to the right of the lettering. This element is so recognizable that with the recent "Share a Coke" campaign, the wave can be used with ideas or names in place of the "Coca-Cola" script.
alternative logo that is widely used

because of how recognizable it is. The bottle itself was originally designed with the soda's two main ingredients in mind, the coca leaf and the kola nut. The coca leaf is narrow at the stem and widens in the middle and curves to a point. The kola bean typically has ridged shell which causes lines that go from end to end. The "contour" bottle, as it is commonly known, reflects the combination of both. The shape of the bottle represents the coca leaf. The base is wide, then it curves in, then widens as you reach the middle part. The middle is wide for approximately a third of the bottles height so that it can be held easily, then it curves inward towards the bottle opening where it is capped. The Coca-Cola logo label or embossed logo goes in the middle area. There are raised vertical ridges that appear around the bottle that represent the kola bean. The label goes across the middles section which is flat and free of the ridges. The logo can be a label, or white lettering, or embossed lettering, and all three versions use the Spencerian script with and
to help people recognize that Coke was now in a can. The
in the 1990's it was used again on cans with the "Always" campaign. Starting back in 2009, the bottle shape has been used frequently used as a
colored red or white and the Spencerian script stretched across the middle.

The disc is also an alternative logo. It is just a circle with a flat red color and the white Spencerian script inside of it. The latest version does have a slight shine on the left edge and a slight shadow on the right edge. Back in 1947 Coca-Cola designed a Red Disc, also known as the ‚Äúbutton‚Äù sign and has been us
ing from time to time since 1947.
were mostly used by shop owners were Coca-Cola was sold,
advertising and decoration. The Red Disc appeared in print advertising up through the 1960‚Äôs
the Arciform or ‚Äúfish tail‚Äù signs began to be used.
have been many variations of the disc
logo, then they added the contour bottle

behind it, then in the 1990's they reused it with the slogan "Always" above it in a green (sometimes blue) banner that followed the curve of the circle on top. In the 2000's it was made flat with no metallic shine and displayed the main
with the wave in it. Most recently they dropped the wave and brought back a subtle shine
that also can stand on its own
, one to represent the nickname for the drink
s most commonly used, "Coke". This uses a serif font and spells "Coke".
This has been updated many times. In the 1980‚Äôs is was bolded, then slanted in the 1990‚Äôs, and streamlined in the 2000‚Äôs.
The identity system and logo has evolved to reflect society quite frequently to go along with the times. Some of the
most effective ways the product has evolved is
through campaigns, in which they usually rebrand the products slightly or dramatically. Most of the time there is a new slogan to go along with the campaign. Some

that really stand the test of time are ones like 1963's "Things go better with Coke.", 1970's "It's the real thing.", 1982's "Coke is it!", 1985's "America's real choice.", 1986's "Red, white & you." (for Coca-Cola Classic), 1986's "Catch the wave." (for New Coke), 1987's
"You can't beat the feeling!.", 1990's "Can't Beat The Real Thing.", 1993's "Always Coca-Cola.", 2000's "Enjoy", 2009's "Open Happiness", and 2014's "Share A Coke".
were included in the Coca-Cola logo
"Drink", "Enjoy", and "Always". The overall theme that Coke
and sharing. These are wonderful messages and really affect people from all around the world.
, the first version of the Coca-Cola logo was capital serif letters in the first newspaper advertisement for the drink which appeared in the Atlanta Journal on May 29th, 1886
. The original version of the Spencerian script was reportedly first used in June 16, 1887 but it took over 5 years to register it
he trademark registration was granted on January 31, 1893
ntil this point the logo was always hand written so it was not always consistent in design in regards to the flow and thickness of the letters, the slant may have been a little off,
the tail to the left of the first "o" was not always drawn in, which was dropped anyway in the more modern versions

However just before the Spencerian script version was granted its first trademark from the patent office, in 1890-1891 a fancy serif font version was used sometimes. The "C"s both had tails on the bottom and the tops of them swirled into itself like a spiral. Below the lowest part of the spiral on the inside there were two swirls that dangled from it
. There was another variation with diamonds floating inside the "C"s instead of the dangling swirls in 1892.
But once the Spencerian script version was trademarked that is all that was used and the word trademark would appear on the ta
required companies to re-register their trademarks
In the early twentieth century, t
he colors red and white were prominent in the adverts while green was an accent color used quite frequently. The ads consisted of both graphic design that focused on just typography
center piece was either the contour bottle, or soda fountains,
sophisticated looking women holding the glasses or bottles of Coke.
By the 1920's, the lettering and symmetry
was closer to what the modern version looks like except for the
above the logo in much of their signage and advertising, along with the infamous "5 cents per glass" pricing

By the 1940s, the word Trademark was removed from the tail and placed underneath the logo and the script had evolved to its most familiar design in which the script was slightly altered to be even and more circular, meaning that each letter had the perfect slant and the form of each letter is more rounded. This is the form that we still see today. Also in 1941 the public saw the first use of the nickname "Coke" as an official trademark (Logopedia).
Up until 1957 the words Coca-Cola were blown into the glass
. The fishtail design was introduce d in 1958 and lasted until 1969. The script was placed in a red
on both the left and the right whi
ch made it look like fish tails.
was first introduced in 1960. The body was red with a white diamond as the center piece outlined in silver
he Script logo was inside of the diamond
a line drawing of the contour bottle
so that people would recognize that it was Coca-Cola
first overhaul and is commonly known as the "Harlequin design",
because it was made up entirely of a
he logo for "Coke" started appearing in on the aluminum cans too, and one of the first slogans to be used with the new graphic was the "Things Go Better With Coke"
from the campaign of the same name

introduced the "Arden Square" as their brand new logo. It featured the classic Spencerian script in white with the famous 'Dynamic Ribbon, or 'White Swirl' for the first time. Above the script in sans-serif was the word "Enjoy".
All three elements were enclosed in
a red square. This logo lasted for almost 20 years until Coke was re-branded in 1987

By 1970 the can reflected the ‚ÄúArden Square‚Äù. This is when the most common look of the can was introduced. It was all red, the script was sideways on one side of the can with the wave accompanying it, and on the other side was the Coke logo along with another wave.
In 1971 a song from a Coca-Cola commercial called "I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing", produced by Billy Davis, became a
hit single and was featured in the famous
n 1977 the bottle itself was granted registration as a trademark
because of its presence and since an
earlier study showed that only less than 1% of Americans could not identify the bottle by shape alone

For the first time in its history, Coca Cola was no longer the most popular soft drink. By this point Pepsi's popularity and sales had surpassed their own and the company was in full damage control mode. In response
the company changed its formula and launched a bold new brand, snubbing its script logo in favor of a thick slab serif font to accompany their rebrand as Coke
The History of the Coca-Cola Logo
). Enter "New Coke" which was Coca-Cola's solution to beat out Pepsi. The company
ula hoping to win the cola war. I
instead of the traditional Coca-Cola. They also added silver to outline the word "Coke" and added another layer to the wave which was silver. In addition to that

they slapped a silver label on the top of the can with the word "New" in it. Despite all their efforts and regardless if the drink tasted good, many long time Coke drinkers and fans created such a backlash that Coca-Cola
was forced to bring back the original formula.
"Classic" was added to the name to differentiate the two sodas
and New Coke was renamed to Coke II

Throughout the history of Coke, their advertising has been cherished by many. Four periods that stood out were the
century going back to Hilda Clark,

a famous singer and actress from the late Nineteenth Century. From 1899-1903 her image was used on a wide variety of advertising materials such as serving and change trays, signage, trading cards, and clocks, among other things (Nestor, 2014).

Santa Claus has been an annual holiday tradition for Coca-Cola. Beginning in the 1930s "the Coca-Cola company was looking for ways to increase sales of their product during winter" to increase sales since the end of the year was a slow period of business "and they turned to a talented commercial illustrator named Haddon Sundblom, who created a series of memorable drawings" which were inspired by Clement Clark Moore's 1822 poem "A Visit from St. Nicholas" (The Claus That Refreshes). Common myth is that Coca-Cola is credited with inventing the modern image of Santa Claus as an old man in a red-and-white suit, but illustrations from the early
hey only helped shape Santa for the modern audience.
Polar Bears are part of the holiday
season as well. They were used from time
to time going back to a 1922 in
French print ad, however in 1993 Coca-Cola started
when the "Always Coca-Cola" campaign began. The campaign began with the Creative Artists Agency (and later

Edge Creative) with an initial run of 27 commercials designed to appeal to specific audiences. It was a world-wide campaign using computer animation. Typically in the commercials, the polar bears would watch the Northern Lights as if it was a movie and they drank from bottles of Coca-Cola.¬†
Technology influenced the evolution of Coca-Cola and the development of their corporate identity
logo in various ways. In regards to the cocaine
started using spent leaves instead of fresh ones after 1904 because
of the controversy regarding the subject. The spent leaves
only had trace levels of cocaine left in them yet still provided the necessary taste. Since then, Coca-Cola uses cocaine free coca leaf extract prepared at a Stephan Company in Maywood New Jersey.
Printed materials were the first form of advertising until radio commercials and then television commercials. Most recently with the new age of the
. Their websites are full of everything from their corporate information, their stance on real world issues, history of their company
t has been a great medium for advertising in many ways including
advantage of technology to reach out to the public in order to establish their presence and show that they are modern, hip, that they produce refreshing drinks, and

to incorporate aluminum cans in the 1960's
and the most recently aluminum bottles in the 2000's. These advancements allowed

PET plastic bottle. It became popular for a lot of reasons: it doesn‚Äôt break; it‚Äôs re-sealable, lightweight and recyclable".(100 years of the Coca-Cola Bottle). Most recently the company has started to promote the PlantBottle which is made of packaging that uses a process to turn sugarcane in a key component of the bottle. It is said that "The material looks and functions just like traditional PET plastic, but has a lighter footprint on the planet and its scarce resources" (PlantBottle).
identity unique is the script plays a big part, it is classy and nostalgic, recognized by the whole world even

it is not translated. The bottle is unique that even though it has evolved it is still recognizable. The script is very versatile and can be used with various elements and never be overshadowed. When the colors are inverted they are actually even more powerful and striking as the red really stands out. The script and wave can be updated (like in the 1990's to 2000's) to show more flare and yet can easily be reverted back to
simplest form and look even more modern than ever.

arketing is always trying to reach out to the world and show that Coca-Cola cares about the world. The Coca-Cola Company has a huge portfolio including various flavors and variations of the flagship drink that have come and gone and still have many still in production such as Diet Coke, Coke Zero, Cherry Coke, Caffeine-Free Coca-Cola, Diet Coke Caffeine-Free, Coca-Cola Cherry, Coca-Cola Zero, and Coca-Cola Vanilla.
